string_table.string: Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.
Closed captions. Press the spacebar to toggle captions on and off.
Skip navigation. Press enter to return to the slide.
To watch this video, use the preview feature in Storyline 360, upload your published output to a server, publish to Review 360, or switch to static video quality.
Streaming video is unavailable for local playback.

slidelink.displaytext: Who we are is who we serve
What is Race? What is Racism?
Race as a system of power
Harmon Family Financial and Housing Instability
Reflection Time: Impacts of Our History
Section 2: Combating the Impacts of Bias
How Do Stress and Trauma Affect Us?
Impacts of Stress and Trauma on the Harmon Family
Harmon Family Experience of Trauma-Informed Care
Reflection Time: Your Experience of Trauma-Informed Care

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

terms.term: Bias is an individual's prejudice that is activated during quick decision making. (Example: People might show their bias by quickly dismissing or disagreeing with anyone who aligns with that opposing political view.)

Disparities are a noticeable and usually significant difference or dissimilarity between individuals. There is a disparity, for example, of the wages of women compared to men. Statistically women earn an average of 80 cents for every dollar a man does. For women of color the gap is wider.

Diversity includes qualities and conditions that are different from ones own and outside the group to which we belong yet are present in other individuals and groups. These differences include, but are not limited to, age, gender, ethnicity, ability, class, language, and so on. For example, language diversity at the workplace can introduce communication complications, but can also provide benefits to the business when multiple languages are spoken.

Equity is a state in which belonging to a particular social group does not determine an individual's level of success. Rather, all groups have access to the resources and opportunities necessary to eliminate gaps and improve the quality of their lives. For example, an equity-based policy of affirmative action can be used to increase college enrollment opportunities, thereby eliminating gaps in access to college specifically for minority groups.

Inclusion is when people are invited to show up fully and their differences are understood as a part of their strength. Who you are is part of the value youre adding. For example, an inclusive organization company recognizes the inherent value that different experiences, cultures, and perspectives bring.

Inequities are the differences in outcomes between groups that are rooted in unfairness and injustice. For example, it is an inequity when two men commit the same crime but one gets convicted and the other doesn't because he can afford to hire a better lawyer.

Institutional Racism is the discriminatory treatment, unfair policies and practices, and differing levels of opportunities within single institutions, based on race. An example is the predominance of underfunded school systems being in communities of color, contributing to crowded classrooms, limited resources and overburdened educators.

Internalized Racism is an internalization of racial oppression by the racially subordinated that involves both conscious and unconscious acceptance of a racial hierarchy. For example, a black ballerina assuming she will never become a principal dancer because most of the ballerina leads are white women.

Interpersonal Racism is the expression of racism between individuals. It occurs when individuals interact, and their private beliefs and prejudices affect their interactions. This might be, for example, verbal and non-verbal behaviors that communicate exclusion, rejection, and disrespect.

Intersectionality is the complex, cumulative way in which the effects of multiple forms of discrimination combine, overlap, or intersect especially in the experiences of marginalized individuals or groups. (Example: A woman can identify herself as a Black female [ethnic background], English professor [profession], and mother [family structure].)

Prejudice is a preconceived judgment or opinion usually based on limited information. Stereotypes, omissions, and distortions of facts all contribute to the development of prejudice. For example, a person may be judged or perceived as either hardworking or lazy based on their age, appearance, or gender.

Race is a social construct developed by Europeans in order to establish and maintain dominance over people of color. Therefore, a DNA test can give you the information about where your ancestors are from, but that is not the same as telling you what your race is.

Racism is a system of power or oppression based on race, producing an inherent superiority by a dominant racial group over a non-dominant racial group. An example of racism is racial profiling by law enforcement that leads to Blacks being pulled over more often.

Structural Racism is a system by which public policies, institutional practices, cultural representations, and other norms work in various and often reinforcing ways to perpetuate power disparities based on race. For example, structures that lead to minority women being 35 percent less likely to receive a job referral than white men.
